review_title: Customer Service higher management is not concerned about its employees
pros: You'll have an amazing time at Amazon due to its work culture. However, the salary slabs at Amazon is very low compared to the market trends. They'll make you work and pay for overtime as well. But the only problem is their basic salary is very less.
cons: I really enjoyed working at Amazon until the management started making all the changes which were against employees. They kept increasing the metrics and lowering the salaries. Removed Bonus and every other benefit from which we employees were happy. So I left the company.

review_title: Stories are true even in a pandemic
pros: Full-time is able to receive good healthcare benefits.
cons:
All of the stories are true regarding how amazon supervisors/managers treat employees are true. If you are not perfect and fast, you are not amazon standard.

Several employees have been making complaints regarding this talking with floor managers or supervisors, but it likely wont change since the demand for groceries or products are high.

They track your movement or if you are idle which if you need to use the bathroom, you might as well do less than the 5 min rule to avoid push back.

Was told by one of the managers that we are supposed to take 3 minutes out of our 15 minute breaks (we would get 2) in order to go back to the floor and set up the cart.

I only lasted a few days there and I do not plan to go back. I will only be using the service rather. Also employee discount is not as good as it should be, because other companies provide better discounts.

review_title: Good for a first job - avoid if you have experience
pros:
You get exposure to a high volume of scheduling and also a lot of outside project s that you can get involved in. 
You can learn a lot from Amazon as you will be working with many different hiring managers , recruiters etc and will need to learn how to navigate them 
Good team members who under stand your struggle as there are whole teams of just recruitment coordinators
Good tools that you can learn and you become organised very quickly
cons:
Work-life balance is probably the worst I have experienced and I have worked in a fair amount of roles.
There is a real culture of throwing eachother under the bus . If you make a mistake  ... You will be made very very aware of it and sometimes people escalate to your manager for minimal reasons
The main benefit is a sign on bonus and stocks however .. your stocks do not become accessible until you're with Amazon 2 years ...a long time especially on a fixed term contract .

There is a lack of job stability in the Recruitment coordinator role as everyone is hired in on a fixed term contract or through an agency, you can feel the unease amongst your team with this 

The benefits are ok but not fantastic . Apart from stocks the only other benefits are healthcare and pension which most tech companies offer in ireland. No support whatsoever working from home . All you will get is a laptop... No chair/desk/ screen .

review_title: Dead End if you are tech savvy
pros:
1) Gets to work with business owners from IIMs.
2) Gets to experiment with stuff as the team is in startup stage.
3) Office location is good. (WTC BLR)
cons:
1) The lazy employees who work 3 hrs a day might get promoted and the one working hard 10-12 hrs/day will not even get a chance to discuss about promotion with his manager.
2) The team culture set by the leadership has turned to be a demoralizing example.
3) 90% of the time you'll be working on ad-hoc tasks for others, automating their stuff. These will never be recognized by your manager to support you to grow.
4) All the focus is on delivering tasks, whether the process handles the corner cases no one cares.
5) Too much manual work even from automation employees like downloading a file from some portal (cannot be automated due to authentication token), running script, etc on daily basis. 
6) The team is running in survival mode.
7) No code review.
8) Expectation setting mismatch if you're tech savvy as your manager would want you to move towards operational excellence.
9) No work from home policy forced by manager.
10) Higher leadership not at all helpful in achieving your personal goals.

pros: Great salary, amazing product's, interesting customer conversations
cons:
I took the job as it was a dream job for me. Having incredible high hopes. When i started my manager trusted me to do the work, had onboarding remote due to covid has been hard as you won't hear what people are talking about. Around 160+ and still growing products. I found it difficult to focus and learn due to so many products. Willing to do the work and trusting my colleagues to onboard me in the right way i started to work. Then a new manager came in to collaborate with the other manager and suddenly i felt them watching my every step, negative comments instead of trying to understand or help, micromanage started to come in to the picture and my incredible boss has totally switched into something i don't agree with anymore. People work late night's to keep up with work, people work weekends as well and managers would announce deadlines at 16.00 on a Friday for huge projects that needed to be done by Monday morning meaning everyone had to work on their weekends and no one gets extra paid for that. 

From being a great team to work in where i felt trust it has gone down hill. Managers texting in the mornings to check if you are working and what you are doing. Managers went from wanting to teach us to getting mad if we asked for help or showed any insecurity.

It has turned so bad that i have cried several times a week, i think about how to improve or what to do non stop. It has taken over my life so much and team members are quitting. I have yet to make up my mind as in the end i actually love what i do and i think Amazon web services is an incredible company and products. I took this job wanting to stay for at least 5 years but now I don't know anymore. I myself feel burned out and i know others in my team feel the same.

Also the company is so big so it's pretty much impossible to talk to anyone about how you feel. 

My tip for anyone thinking about taking this job. The job is super interesting, you will get paid alot but you will work over time alot and it's very stressful, your territories are so big that you will do a job that actually requires 10 employees for, you will feel overwhelmed many times, this is fast paced on another level. You might get burned out. It's definitely an experience either way. You are a small ant here.

Best of luck for trying. It's not an easy job!

review_title: If you want career growth this the place to be
job_title: Program Manager II in Seattle, WA
pros: If you want a career growth or you need to prove to yourself and peers that you are good at what you do, this is the place to be. Amazon will give you as much scope as you want for that growth. Being ambitious is encouraged and rewarded as long as you deliver results. At my previous company there was a lot of politics and I was stuck as a PgM1 despite delivering Sr level PgM work. I came to Amazon and while I was under-leveled I was able to go from PgM II to a PgMIII in less than a year. I didn't change anything about who I was as a Pgm or what I did as a PgM, I was just fairly recognize for my work at Amazon.
cons:
Work Life Balance. If you want that growth just know that it will come at a steep price of your work life balance. Except to work at least 50 hours a week minimum and upwards of 70 hours a week during certain period. Amazon is very frugal meaning they expect a lot out of one person that could easily be a two person role. Its not the place where you are going to have kids and be able to know them and watch them grow up and be an involved parents. I'd recommend Amazon to someone who doesn't have kids or someone with kids with teenagers. This is not an environment that's friendly to people with young children that need their attention. 

Compensation: For the amount of work that you do at Amazon, the money is not worth it

Benefits: You pay for some of your benefits so take that into account when you think about your total comp. Its not much but if you are coming from somewhere where they provide free healthcare, it's something you should factor

pros:
Paid very well (especially night shift). Also paid weekly!

VERY COVID-compliant - strict social distancing measures, one-way systems etc.

Communication is pretty good. 

Nice to talk to workers from various cultures. 

Most team leaders and workers are friendly and approachable.

Variety of roles available, so if you are put in a position that you are not keen on (e.g. you had worked an entire shift in that role the night before), then team leaders would happily swap you out.

Free hot drinks. Use of microwaves etc. Various food and drink vending machines. Lots of water dispensers.

There are communication boards for workers to write their questions and managers to write their responses.

Lockers are available for your stuff.
cons:
Offsite parking via shuttle bus adds time to the commute. This is about 15 minutes away from the warehouse (so 30 mins there and back). However, you are compensated for this (but this pay is often paid late, so best to keep a record).

Shifts are often cancelled with a few hours' notice if they don't need many workers if there are fewer packages to be sorted. This can be unsettling for night shift workers who will sleep during the day, only to wake up to find that the shift is cancelled - this can mess up your sleeping pattern if you are stuck at home awake all night. I did hear one or two moans about the impact of cancelling shifts on workers' pay, so if you are looking for a guaranteed income each week then this may not be suitable (akin to a zero-hours type situation).

The 8-hour shifts are very demanding - from the moment you step in until the moment you leave there is little time for a breather (30 mins break). During Christmas, the shifts were 11 hours long, but you had two 30 minute breaks and the extra time on shift would alleviate some of the pressure (more time to sort parcels, overlap with day-shift workers).

pros:
1. Big problems - At Amazon, no problem is pushed aside as too hard to solve. In fact, they go after the really hard and insolvable problems and then throw talent, time and resources towards solving them. In my time there, pretty much every team I worked with was solving a "holy grail" problem in their field and actually making progress towards it. There is no dearth of interesting projects, teams or ideas to work on.

2. Structure and thinking - There is a lot of document writing at Amazon, in case you have not heard. While some people do not like that part of the job much, I think the required meetings and documents force every employee to truly think about their job and what they are doing. Producing the write-ups and getting them ready to face up to a room of very detailed scrutiny and questioning forces you to think through every aspect of your business. it is really a very valuable skill that Amazon does a great job of developing.

3. Ownership - Amazon treats you like an owner - a grown up. You have a job to do and you are empowered to do it. There are checks and balances, of course, but you truly do own your business. You make the assessments, take the risks, justify your decisions and ultimately reap the benefits or learn from your mistakes and move on. There are not many fall-backs and layers to catch you if you are not moving your business forward. Not a lot of finger poitning for failures either, that I saw. In fact, I would say that if you do not act like an owner, you will not be successful at Amazon. You have to embrace the responsibility and run with it.

4. Smart People - You'll hear this a lot and personally, I think some of the talk is overblown but Amazon does indeed have some very, very smart and talented people working there. I know its a cliche, but I did learn a lot from most people I worked with there - and again, I say, most, not all :-) are just genuinely nice people. I would work again with these people without hesitation. I think the leadership there is especially great - just really smart, experienced people with sharp instincts, great insights and lots of ambition. It was really fun working with the folks I did.
cons:
1. Structure and documentation - What I said above about structure and documentation, while its great to create clarity and shape your thinking, it can get in the way of actually doing your work. Everybody at Amazon is juggling so much and constantly writing high quality documents can get exhausting. The secret here, as in any job, is to balance the strategic against the operational and prioritize ruthlessly. I cannot say I was always effective at it - but I tried till my last day and now have the benefit of hind sight as well :-)

2. Culture - I think some people could have a tough time adjusting to the culture - its tough, expectations are high and there is not always a lot of hand holding ( in fact, it would be very rare). I think you have to embrace or at least accept it and focus on the positives. Your team makes a huge difference - so hopefully you're lucky and end up with a great manager and great team mates. If you're looking for free food and onsite massages - you certainly will be disappointed. You can end up overworked and resentful if you are not good at prioritizing your work and your life and making trade-offs.

3. People/Politics - I started to see a lot of the "we are the best in the world" mentality start to show up. I don't believe that everyone that works at Amazon is a genius and seeing that attitude crop up every now and then was annoying. Every company has inside politics and even though Amazon tries really hard to believe there is no politics, there is certainly that to deal with. No more than any other company that I can tell, but it can get frustrating when you're working so hard and so long to get derailed by that kind of thing.

pros: Great Social interaction, a lot of employees have great ethics and work hard. The wage is good, there are 401Ks and insurance coverage, everything is ensured to be fair and they even allow employees to voice their causes like BLM or Pride yet they DO try to avoid the unwanted politics which is one of my favorites. There are VOAs (Voice of Associate boards) where you can write out or voice your concerns and a lot of the time you get a response where it looks like someone takes it into consideration.
cons: Sometimes it's always hot including in the winter and management doesn't always listen to thoughts or suggestions. There are some employees that slip through the cracks who barely work and get moved up and some of us are kept solely to one position and tend to get overlooked. Even based on performance or experience or tenure.

pros: The managers and PAs are nice, my coworkers are also nice. Great benefits, low cost and great coverage. I have only worked for less than 3 months, yet I am eligible for a promotion (to afm)
cons: I'm a picker and they expect us to work like machines, the pick and transition times are hard to achieve, yet you are reminded of them by someone every week. No listening to music so it gets boring and repetitive. Not very lenient with break times, if you continously take too long you will get written up. It's fall time but it seems to constantly be 70 degrees Fahrenheit and they could put a few more fans in to make sure every station gets cooled.

pros:
Weekly Pay
Great chance of promotion (if you’re a Latino male, or if you’re fraternizing with a Shift Assistant or someone in a Leadership role.)
cons: Everything about this job is terrible. The pay is terrible for the amount of physical labor you’re expected to do. “Mandatory” working hours (aka slavery) during peak season. The management is paid well, so they walk around on their high horses, power tripping and micro-managing all day. Like seriously, how do you micro-manage at a sortation warehouse? All we do is put packages into a bag. They find a way. I guess it’s because they have the time and energy to do so, because they do absolutely no physical work. And the physical work is 95% of the operation. Some managers have the decency to hop in and help. The majority do not. They walk around on their phones and computers, acting like they’re doing something. My advice is to work minimally if that’s what you’re paid. Get in, do your job, leave. Ignore the drama and chaos around you. It’s not your problem and you’re not paid for it.

When applying (depending on how you did) in my case at least I had no idea what job the posting was for. I didn't know if I was going to be lifting heavy items all day, walking 10 miles picking orders, or standing still scanning and sorting. Most people are rotated around but even with that said I had no idea walking into it as it wasnt explained very well. 

They essentially toss spaghetti (us) at the wall and wait to see what sticks. Not a great way to optimize people using their individual strengths, abilities, and preferences.

review_title: It is a good place to work
job_title: Seller Support in San Jose, San Jose
pros:
- There's always someone to turn to if you need assistance with a subject and most people are friendly all the time. 
- Managers, supervisors, and advisors have an open-door policy that associates can turn to if needed.
- If there's a situation you need to talk about your personal life, your peers, or anything that affects your productivity in any way, your direct superiors often try to help you find a balance for you to get it in order.
cons:
- Depending on the department, things can be annoying and stressful as some sellers will call for things that they can do on their own but don't want to. Or will try to get their way with things that may not be in your control. 
- Some departments take more calls than others
- In my own experience, applying for a higher position or different department while being inside the company can be very stressful. More often than not my metrics were pretty high in my team, but from the applications I submitted, I only received a few replies from the hiring manager, maybe 2 out of 10, to later find out that those positions were filled with completely new employees. That, or as mentioned, never received a status update in the application.
- If you are planning or currently studying, you NEED to plan for your classes in advance and as soon as they are announced, because supervisors will TRY to help with schedules for you to study, but they need your chronogram for them to make the request to HR, but is not always a guarantee as HR will approve the change of schedule (depends on the availability of the department you are in).

Shifts are about 11 hours long of just mindless picking items from shelves, scanning them, putting them in bins, then putting bins on conveyer belts.
You get tracked on your rate of picking, and if you are going too slow or scanning incorrect bins/items, your "productivity" drops a lot and management comes finds you to talk to you.
You are not allowed cellphones or any electronic devices in the warehouse, so while doing mindless tasks, you're stuck listening to the sound of ventilation. They don't even have a radio.
They ONLY Have washrooms on the 1st floor, so if you need to go, consider an 8 minute drop in productivity in which manager will still find you and ask what's going on.

Some cons, definitely more than pros. You are not seen as an employee, but as a number and rate. Management gets really pushy when youre going too slow or anything, expect them to come up and tell you to hurry up. Warehouse equipment is horrible, your'e better off just holding those boxes than using the conveyor belts amazon has (any "fix" they do the the conveyor belts never lasts more than that shift). MET (mandatory over time) you dont have a choice in the matter, you have to take that extra time. 
 Too many to list honestly, if youre desperate for work go for it, but if you have other options, would highly recommend looking at those other options.

review_title: Very flexible, but too demanding on drivers
job_title: Independent Contractor in Fort Worth, TX
pros:
- You pick the time blocks.
- Independent work.
- Pay rate is pretty good for the low level of training/expertise required.
cons:
- No compensation for overtime, and you will go over many times, especially when learning.
- Routes often end up over half an hour from the station, and often far from home. You are typically at the end of your pay block, but if you have to return undeliverable packages all the way back to the station, it's on your time; again, without pay. This is not a rare occurrence.
- Your standing with the company drops very rapidly, even for things out of your control. I had two late packages on one route during morning rush hour traffic and my standing dropped to Fair (2 out of 4). Any lower and I risk being fired. I've only been doing this for two weeks, so obviously there isn't any allowance for new drivers to learn the job.
- Warehouse procedures differ, but the one I use causes starting delays due to their batch loading method (30+ drivers must park and load at the same time). I am often over 20 minutes into my block before I can exit the warehouse to begin sorting my packages, which takes another 10 minutes. Again, there is no consideration for delays in this process when tagging drivers for late deliveries.
- No additional pay for distant routes. I've had multiple 3-hour routes over 80 miles round trip (with 30+ stops), which obviously cost more on fuel, not to mention time since distant blocks often get you back an hour after your block is over.
- In general, Amazon will overload your route and they under-compensate for time to deliver on distant routes or downtown routes that have many apartment stops (which take much more time). This causes undue burden on the drivers, affecting their standing, while having no apparent effect on the poor scheduling or warehouse procedures. Good for a little extra money, but don't expect it to be just compensation for your efforts.
